content.webTitle: Nations League final: Ryan Babel impressed by mature Dutch youngsters

fields.headline: Nations League final: Ryan Babel impressed by mature Dutch youngsters
fields.bodyText: Dutch football has a tendency to lurch from boom to bust and back again. But as Holland prepare for the Nations League final against Portugal on Sunday they sense the good times are returning again. “Holland have struggled for the past few years,” says Ryan Babel, one of the team’s elder statesmen at 32. “But we are slowly coming back to where we belong. And this generation has a lot more potential to grow.” Babel’s eyes light up when he is asked about Matthijs de Ligt, Frenkie de Jong and Donny van de Beek, three dazzling prodigies who have emerged from Ajax. But it is not only their talent that impresses him but their maturity. “When I compare them to when I was their age, these players already take so much responsibility,” says Babel. “They are so mature. For example, De Ligt made a mistake against England but it didn’t affect his confidence. He just carried on doing the same things we asked him to do and made up for his mistake by a goal.” Davy Pröpper, who looked a much more progressive player in Holland’s 3-1 win over England than he often does in Brighton’s defensive straitjacket, concurs. “We have a really young group, with really talented players and at the moment they are making a quick jump in level,” he says. “We can compete with the best teams in Europe. It’s really brilliant to see.” Both players credit manager Ronald Koeman as another key factor. Babel says: “If the vision is not right and if the right group of players is not together, it doesn’t come together.” Pröpper stresses how much spirit Koeman has added to a team who had failed to qualify for Euro 2016 and the 2018 World Cup and yet beat France and Germany in the Nations League group stages and England in the semi-final. “We have a group who have stayed together for most of the games, so you can really build a good spirit,” he says. “There is no magic formula. We lost our opening game against France but there something changed in our heads. After that we played some really good matches.” Portugal will be another step up. The Oranje have won only two of 13 matches against them since 1990, including the Battle of Nuremberg at the 2006 World Cup, which featured four red and 16 yellow cards. Babel, part of the squad that day, is expecting a different game and result. “It is a big test,” he says. “[Cristiano] Ronaldo is a quality player. But I am confident with our defence that we can make it difficult for him. We will be prepared.”
